newsitem.title: CHINA: China customs to tighten tax collection.
newsitem.headline: China customs to tighten tax collection.

text.p: China's customs authorities aim to boost tax revenues by improving the evaluation of prices of imports and exports, the China Daily said on Thursday.

"Customs authorities around the country need to improve their export and import price assessment system to prevent loss of revenues because of underestimated prices," the newspaper quoted Qian Guanlin, director of the General Administration of Customs, as saying.
More accurate estimates of the value of imported and exported goods would help authorities calculate the proper amount of tariffs to be charged, Qian said.
He did not say what specific measures would be adopted.
Customs authorities would also start auditing the prices of goods imported by the processing industry for export but that are sold within China instead, Qian said.
The audit would also cover tariff-free imports by foreign-funded enterprises, he said without elaborating.
Some firms involved in the processing trade would soon be allowed to set up bonded warehouses to store materials for their own use, he said.
Customs had chosen a pilot group of 18 high-technology firms to have customs officials assigned to them, he said.
Customs authorities would also try to crack down on smuggling by targeting a growing number of gangs, he said.
Customs officials had uncovered 6,130 smuggling cases involving goods worth 9.68 billion ($1.17 billion) in 1996, he said.
